text: CRM No 4—1998
label: BODY

text: he underground railroad was per-
label: BODY

text: haps the most dramatic protest
label: BODY

text: action against slavery in United
label: BODY

text: States history. It was a clandestine
label: BODY

text: operation that began during the colonial period,
label: BODY

text: later became part of organized abolitionist activity
label: BODY

text: in the 19th century, and reached its peak in the
label: BODY

text: period 1830-1865. The story of the underground
label: BODY

text: railroad is one of individual sacrifice and heroism
label: BODY

text: of enslaved people to reach freedom from
label: BODY

text: bondage.
label: BODY

text: In passing Public Law 101-628 in 1990,
label: BODY

text: Congress directed the National Park Service “to
label: BODY

text: study the underground railroad, its routes, and
label: BODY

text: operations in order to preserve and interpret this
label: BODY

text: aspect of American history.” This legislation further
label: BODY

text: required that the study be completed in coopera-
label: BODY

text: tion with an advisory committee representing
label: BODY

text: experts in historic preservation, African-American
label: BODY

text: history, United States history, and members of the
label: BODY

text: general public with special interest and experience
label: BODY

text: in the underground railroad. Congress further
label: BODY

text: required that escape routes to Mexico as well as
label: BODY

text: Canada be considered in the study. The
label: BODY

text: Washington Office of the National Park Service
label: BODY

text: (NPS) requested that the Denver Service Center
label: BODY

text: undertake this project in consultation with all
label: BODY

text: involved NPS regions. Over the next several years,
label: BODY

text: this advisory committee worked with the NPS plan-
label: BODY

text: ning team on gathering data, public involvement,
label: BODY

text: and developing a range of alternatives.
label: BODY

text: The number of possible sites and structures
label: BODY

text: associated with the underground railroad story is
label: BODY

text: immense. The underground railroad is every route
label: BODY

text: the enslaved took, or attempted to take, to freedom.
label: BODY

text: It is a vast network of paths and roads, through
label: BODY

text: swamps and over mountains, along and across
label: BODY

text: rivers and even by sea, that cannot be documented
label: BODY

text: with precision. The Underground Railroad Special
label: BODY

text: Resource Study involved consultation with 34
label: BODY

text: states, two territories, hundreds of interested indi-
label: BODY

text: viduals and organizations around the country, as
label: BODY

text: well as Canada and the Caribbean. The study con-
label: BODY

text: sidered 380 suggestions about potential sites of sig-
label: BODY

text: nificance to the underground railroad story. Since
label: BODY

text: the study was finished additional sites have been
label: BODY

text: identified. Additional research has identified 42
label: BODY

text: sites as having the highest potential to meet estab-
label: BODY

text: lished National Historic Landmark criteria for
label: BODY

text: national significance. The NPS is completing
label: BODY

text: National Register of Historic Places forms and sub-
label: BODY

text: mitting these for designation as National Historic
label: BODY

text: Landmarks.
label: BODY

text: Given the national significance of the story,
label: BODY

text: the need for long-term preservation of resources,
label: BODY

text: the public enjoyment potential, and the current
label: BODY

text: amount of public ownership, the underground rail-
label: BODY

text: road story could become an example of the “new
label: BODY

text: wave” national park unit—a cooperative or partner-
label: BODY

text: ship park. Cooperative or partnership efforts, if suc-
label: BODY

text: cessful, should reduce NPS staffing and develop-
label: BODY

text: ment requirements and operating costs.
label: BODY

text: Through working with the URAC, the public,
label: BODY

text: and NPS regions and parks, five alternative con-
label: BODY

text: cepts were developed for preserving, commemorat-
label: BODY

text: ing, and interpreting resources associated with the
label: BODY

text: underground railroad. All of these concepts were
label: BODY

text: intended to enhance public understanding and
label: BODY

text: appreciation of the underground railroad and to
label: BODY

text: preserve its many important resources. Each con-
label: BODY

text: cept is briefly described below:
label: BODY

text: Concept A. At a newly established commem-
label: BODY

text: orative, interpretive, educational, and research cen-
label: BODY

text: ter, visitors would come to understand the whole
label: BODY

text: story of the underground railroad and its signifi-
label: BODY

text: cance in their area or region and in United States
label: BODY

text: history. Resources related to the underground rail-
label: BODY

text: road would be fully inventoried and documented.
label: BODY

text: Concept B. An appreciation of the under-
label: BODY

text: ground railroad would be accomplished by improv-
label: BODY

text: ing existing interpretive programs and by imple-
label: BODY

text: menting new programs that would provide visitors
label: BODY

text: with a complete, in-depth understanding of the
label: BODY

text: underground railroad while focusing on local
label: BODY

text: aspects of the story of the site.
label: BODY

text: Concept C. Visitors would have an opportu-
label: BODY

text: nity to encounter a concentration of underground
label: BODY

text: railroad resources over a large geographic area (up
label: BODY

text: to several hundred miles). These areas could
label: BODY

text: include National Historic Landmarks and existing
label: BODY

text: NPS units associated with the underground rail-
label: BODY

text: road story, documented escape routes used by
label: BODY

text: enslaved Americans, structures and sites associated
label: BODY

text: with personalities and aspects of the underground
label: BODY

text: railroad story, and opportunities to illustrate the
label: BODY

text: John C. Paige
label: TITLE

text: NPS Study to Preserve
label: HH1

text: and Interpret the UGRR
label: HH1

text: CRM No 4—1998
label: BODY

text: international connection to the underground rail-
label: BODY

text: road.
label: BODY

text: Concept D. The history, meaning, signifi-
label: BODY

text: cance, and legacy of the underground railroad
label: BODY

text: would be remembered through a single commemo-
label: BODY

text: rative monument. This monument would honor
label: BODY

text: those people who risked or lost their lives to escape
label: BODY

text: the oppression of slavery and reach freedom on the
label: BODY

text: underground railroad and those who assisted them.
label: BODY

text: Concept E. Visitors would have an opportu-
label: BODY

text: nity to travel along trail systems that evoke the per-
label: BODY

text: ilous experience encountered by those who sought
label: BODY

text: freedom through escape on the underground rail-
label: BODY

text: road. A variety of natural resources (e.g., swamps,
label: BODY

text: forests, and rivers) and cultural resources e.g.,
label: BODY

text: underground railroad stations, homes of significant
label: BODY

text: individuals, and archeological sites) along these
label: BODY

text: trail systems would help to bring this story alive. A
label: BODY

text: trail or trails would be designated through the
label: BODY

text: National Trail System Act of 1968, as amended.
label: BODY

text: One option in implementing concept E would be to
label: BODY

text: establish a government-chartered commission or
label: BODY

text: foundation to work toward establishment of the
label: BODY

text: trail(s).
label: BODY

text: The study also included an environmental
label: BODY

text: assessment and a required no-action alternative.
label: BODY

text: On August 11, 1995, the Underground Railroad
label: BODY

text: Advisory Committee made the following recommen-
label: BODY

text: dations:
label: BODY

text: • That the Congress authorize a national
label: BODY

text: Underground Railroad Commission and fund a
label: BODY

text: national initiative to support projects focusing
label: BODY

text: on activities associated with the underground
label: BODY

text: railroad.
label: BODY

text: • That all alternatives identified as concepts A-E
label: BODY

text: in the Underground Railroad Special Resource
label: BODY

text: Study be pursued with equal vigor and simul-
label: BODY

text: taneously as appropriate.
label: BODY

text: • That public and private sector (corporate, uni-
label: BODY

text: versity, organizational) partnerships be encour-
label: BODY

text: aged and pursued wherever possible and
label: BODY

text: appropriate to achieve the varying goals of the
label: BODY

text: underground railroad project.
label: BODY

text: • That an interpretive handbook on the under-
label: BODY

text: ground railroad be researched, written, and
label: BODY

text: published, and that the skills of non-NPS
label: BODY

text: experts be used wherever possible to ensure
label: BODY

text: historical accuracy and the broadest range of
label: BODY

text: interpretation (recently published).
label: BODY

text: • That the mandate of the current Underground
label: BODY

text: Railroad Advisory Committee be extended
label: BODY

text: through congressional funding and NPS imple-
label: BODY

text: mentation stages to ensure project continuity
label: BODY

text: and to maintain project oversight.
label: BODY

text: • That, regardless of the existence of other con-
label: BODY

text: gressional mandates or funding, the National
label: BODY

text: Park Service continue and accelerate its efforts
label: BODY

text: to document and interpret the underground
label: BODY

text: railroad in all parks, memorials, and trails
label: BODY

text: within its jurisdiction.
label: BODY

text: • That the National Capital Regional Office of
label: BODY

text: the National Park Service be authorized to
label: BODY

text: coordinate underground railroad activities
label: BODY

text: throughout the National Park Service.
label: BODY

text: In addition, the study contained findings
label: BODY

text: which included the following:
label: BODY

text: • The underground railroad story is nationally
label: BODY

text: significant.
label: BODY

text: • A few elements of the story are represented in
label: BODY

text: existing NPS units and other sites, but many
label: BODY

text: important resources are not adequately repre-
label: BODY

text: sented and protected.
label: BODY

text: • Many sites remain that meet established crite-
label: BODY

text: ria for designation as National Historic
label: BODY

text: Landmarks.
label: BODY

text: • Many sites are in imminent danger of being
label: BODY

text: lost or destroyed.
label: BODY

text: • There is a tremendous amount of interest in
label: BODY

text: the subject, but little organized coordination
label: BODY

text: and communication among interested individ-
label: BODY

text: uals and organizations.
label: BODY

text: • Some sites have very high potential for preser-
label: BODY

text: vation and visitor use.
label: BODY

text: • No single site or route completely reflects and
label: BODY

text: characterizes the underground railroad. The
label: BODY

text: story and resources involve networks and
label: BODY

text: regions rather than individual sites and trails.
label: BODY

text: • A variety of partnership approaches would be
label: BODY

text: most appropriate for the protection and inter-
label: BODY

text: pretation of the underground railroad. These
label: BODY

text: partnerships could include the federal, state,
label: BODY

text: and local governments along with a variety of
label: BODY

text: private sector involvement.
label: BODY

text: The study was completed and submitted to
label: BODY

text: Congress on February 7, 1996. A series of bills
label: BODY

text: have been offered which would implement some of
label: BODY

text: the study’s alternatives, but Congress has not taken
label: BODY

text: final action on any of these bills. The NPS, through
label: BODY

text: interpretive media and programs, continues to
label: BODY

text: develop new ways to present the underground rail-
label: BODY

text: road story to the public. These programs include
label: BODY

text: the development of an interpretive handbook which
label: BODY

text: would not only interpret the underground railroad,
label: BODY

text: but also serve as a guide. In addition, the NPS is
label: BODY

text: working with Parks Canada to develop a more com-
label: BODY

text: prehensive interpretation of sites associated with
label: BODY

text: the underground railroad. The NPS continues to
label: BODY

text: work toward nominating underground railroad sites
label: BODY

text: and structures as National Historical Landmarks.
label: BODY

text: Meanwhile, organizations and individuals outside
label: BODY

text: the NPS continue to work toward the recognition of
label: BODY

text: the importance of the underground railroad to
label: BODY

text: American history.
label: BODY

text: John C. Paige is a cultural resource specialist for the
label: BODY

text: Resource Planning Division of the NPS Denver
label: BODY

text: Service Center.
label: BODY
